Instructor  Prof. Joel Spencer    wwh 829; x83219; {lowercaselastname}@cims.nyu.edu  Office Hours: Tuesday 3-5      Class Hours  Monday, Wednesday 11-12:15; ciww 317   Recitation  Instructor: Mark Kim   Recitation, Friday, 2-3:15, ciww 317    Click  here    for Mark's website for this course.       General Stuff  This website deals with Algebra II, Spring 2015. Students are expected to have taken Algebra I, though not necessarily from Prof. Spencer and not necessarily Fall 2014. The basic subject matter is Fields, including Galois Theory. (Because this is a transition year, we shall NOT assume that you have taken the Honors Algebra I.)   Questions? Honors Algebra II - Spring 2015- V63.0349       Syllabus  Click here   postscript   LaTeX   pdf  for an outline and lots of information.       Instructor  Prof. Joel Spencer    wwh 829; x83219; {lowercaselastname}@cims.nyu.edu  Office Hours: Tuesday 3-5      Class Hours  Monday, Wednesday 11-12:15; ciww 317   Recitation  Instructor: Mark Kim   Recitation, Friday, 2-3:15, ciww 317    Click  here    for Mark's website for this course.       General Stuff  This website deals with Algebra II, Spring 2015. Students are expected to have taken Algebra I, though not necessarily from Prof. Spencer and not necessarily Fall 2014. The basic subject matter is Fields, including Galois Theory. (Because this is a transition year, we shall NOT assume that you have taken the Honors Algebra I.)   Questions? Undergraduate algebra II, V63.0344     FINAL!       HERE! IS THE TAKE-HOME FINAL, DUE MONDAY MAY 12 5pm.    Typos, both fixed in the present version:    In question 1(c), the definition of G' should read as those elements of S_n (rather than Sym(X)) which commute with G.     In question 5(c), it should read "there exists an n x n invertible matrix B with the..."        Michael Burr's homework solutions are all available here . Let me know if you have trouble opening them.      General    This is the webpage for the course "Algebra II" in Spring 2008 taught by Akshay Venkatesh. The TA is Michael Burr. Both our emails are lastname at cims dot nyu dot edu .   Handouts, homework and announcements will be posted here. Please check this page regularly.             Time and place: The regular meeting time is Monday, Wednesday 11-12:15 in room UC56 Tisch (Monday) and 613 WWH (Wednesday).  The recitations are Wednesday 8am, 515 Silver.   Office hours: My office hours will be Mondays 1--3pm in 827 WWH.  Michael Burr's office hours will be Fridays 1-3pm in 1004 WWH.  From Tuesday February 19, Michael Burr's office hours switch to Tuesday 1--3pm.   Textbook: Herstein's book, Topics in Algebra.     Syllabus:  The main goal is to cover Galois theory (Chapter 5 of Herstein); we'll also  cover some of Chapters 4 and 6.   According to time we may cover further advanced topics.   I will post here a short description of each lecture and the relevant parts of the book as the course progresses.     Assessment: The assessment wil be based 50% final + 25% midterm +  25% homework.  You are welcome (and, in fact, encouraged) to collaborate with other students on the homework, but please indicate clearly the names of other students you collaborated with.       Homework assignments (SEE TOP OF PAGE FOR SOLUTIONS)   Homework 1, posted 29 January, due 6 February in class .   Homework 2, posted February 5, due 13 February in class . (This homework is hard. So don't be discouraged if you don't solve the problems at first. Also, in problem 1, "index" means the number of cosets of H, i.e. the size of A_n divided by the size of H.)   Homework 3, posted February 12, due February 20 in class.    FROM HOMEWORK 4 ONWARDS, THE HOMEWORKS WILL BE DUE ON THURSDAYS. PLEASE GIVE IT TO ME IN MY OFFICE, OR LEAVE IT IN MY MAILBOX.     Homework 4, posted February 21, due 5pm February 28 (THURSDAY).   Homework 5, posted February 29, due 5pm March 6 (Thursday). Sorry about the late posting of this homework!   Homework 6, posted March 7, due 5pm March 13 (Thursday) . Sorry about the late posting...again...  No HOMEWORK OVER BREAK; a practice midterm will be posted shortly.   Practice midterm ; and  solutions .     Midterm and solutions.     Homework 7, posed Friday March 28, due April 3 Thursday .  NOTE: in problem (1), a group action is said to be transitive when it has only one orbit. Also, remember that the polynomial is assumed irreducible for all problems, 1--4.   Homework 8, posted Friday April 4, due April 10 thursday .   Homework 9, postd Friday April 11, due April 17 Thursday. (Note: this will be returned to me by 6pm Friday; I will leave them outside my door for collection if you would like to pick them up before Monday.)    Homework 10, posted Friday April 18, due April 24 Thursday   Homework 11, posted Friday April 25, due May 1 Thursday  and solutions .   THERE IS NO HOMEWORK 12!     List of lecture topics     Lecture 1 (January 23): group actions, definition and basic examples. Orbits and stabilizer.   Lecture 2 (January 28): Group actions continued: orbit-stabilizer theorem. The symmetry group of a cube is isomorphic to S_4.   Lecture 3 (January 30): Simple groups, simplicity of alternating groups.   Lecture 4 (February 4): Completion of proof for simplicity of alternating goroups. Definition of vector spaces, linear independence, bases (Herstein 4.1 and 4.2).   Lecture 5 (February 6): Dual spaces and adjoints.   Lecture 5+1 (February 11): Dual spaces, continued. Why is a dual space ``dual''? Adjoints take injective maps to surjective maps, and vice versa. The dual of a subspace is a quotient, and vice versa.  Lecture 7 (February 13): Inner products. Fisher's inequality.   Lecture 8 (February 20): Inner products continued: existence of an orthonormal basis,  perpendiculars to subspaces. Blah, blah, blah! Modules -- a bit.   Lecture 9 (February 25): Modules, classification of modules over Euclidean rings. Beginning of proof.  Lecture 10 (February 27): Proof of classification of modules over Euclidean rings. Sketch of a second proof: diagonalizing matrices over such rings by row and column operations.   Lecture 11 (March 1): Algebraic numbers and finite extensions of the rational numbers.   Lecture 12 (March 5): Field extensions. Construction of splitting fields.   Lecture 13 (March 10): Construction of splitting fields continued.  Lecture 14 (March 12): Automorphisms. Any two splitting fields are isomorphic.  Lecture 15 (March 24): I forgot.   Lecture 16 (March 26):  MIDTERM !  Lecture 17 (March 31): How to tell whether a polynomial has distinct roots. There exists a finite field of size p^n for every prime p, and any two finite fields of the same size are isomorphic.   Lecture 18 (April 2): More examples of splitting fields and automorphisms between them. Some computations.   Lecture 19 (April 7):??  Lecture 20 (April 9): Main theorem of Galois theory, examples.   Lecture 21 (April 14): Main theorem of Galois theory, examples.   Lecture 22 (April 16): Characterization of field extensions with cyclic Galois group.   Lecture 23 (April 21): Solvable groups. A field extension is solvable if and only if is contained in a Galois extension with solvable Galois group.   Lecture 24 (April 23): Determinant of a matrix via alternating forms ("abstract volumes"). Characteristic polynomial.  Lecture 25 (April 28): Characteristic polynomial, Jordan normal form.   Lecture 26: (April 28+2): Jordan normal form, completed. The Cayley-Hamilton theorem.  Lecture 27 (May 5): question session.
